param.name: projection
param.doc: Projection name. All API requests must specify a projection. Most developers who are using this documentation will use the api projection. However, if you are developing applications for mobile devices, you can substitute mobile for api in any of the sample requests described in the API documentation. Similarly, if you prefer to use the base projection, which is well suited to feed readers, you can substitute base for api in any of the sample requests described in the API documentation.

param.name: regionID
param.doc: Region ID for region-specific standard feeds. See API docs for a list of valid region values.

param.name: feedID
param.doc: Feed ID.

param.name: categoryName
param.doc: Category name for category-specific standard feeds. See API docs for a list of valid category values.

method.name: GET
method.doc: Retrieves a standard YouTube feed. Standard feeds contain lists of videos that either reflect YouTube user behavior, such as top-rated and most viewed video feeds, or were selected by YouTube staff, such as recently featured and mobile video feeds.

param.name: alt
param.doc: The alt parameter specifies the format of the feed to be returned. The default value is atom and this document only explains the format of Atom responses. If you set the parameter value to json-in-script, then you must also set the callback parameter value to identify the callback function to which the API response will be sent.

param.name: author
param.doc: The author parameter restricts the search to videos uploaded by a particular YouTube user. Requesting a standard feed, YouTube will retrieve the standard feed and then filter the response to only include videos uploaded by the specified author. For example, if you request the "Top Rated" feed for user GoogleDevelopers, the API will retrieve the top-rated feed and return a response containing videos in that feed uploaded by user GoogleDevelopers. The API will not return a list of that user's videos ordered by rating.

param.name: callback
param.doc: The callback parameter identifies the callback function to which the API response will be sent. If the value of the alt parameter is jsonc or json-in-script, and you specify a value for the callback parameter, then the API response will be wrapped in a call to the specified function. This parameter is required if the value of the alt parameter is json-in-script.

param.name: fields
param.doc: The fields parameter serves one or both of the following purposes: 1. It identifies the data fields that should be included in a partial API response. 2. It specifies conditions that should be used to filter the result set. See API docs for more details. Note: The fields parameter is currently used for experimental features only.

param.name: fields-language
param.doc: The fields-language parameter is being used temporarily to force the API server to apply new syntax rules affecting requests to retrieve partial API responses. To use the new syntax rules for partial API responses, or to filter results based on the presence of an element that does not contain text content, set the fields-language parameter value to r2. (This is the only valid value for this parameter.)

param.name: max-results
param.doc: The max-results parameter specifies the maximum number of results that should be included in the result set. This parameter works in conjunction with the start-index parameter to determine which results to return. For example, to request the second set of 10 results – i.e. results 11-20 – set the max-results parameter to 10 and the start-index parameter to 11. The default value of this parameter is 25, and the maximum value is 50. However, for displaying lists of videos, we recommend that you set the max-results parameter to 10.

param.name: prettyprint
param.doc: The prettyprint parameter lets you request an XML response formatted with indentations and line breaks. Set the parameter's value to true to have the response formatted as such. The default parameter value is false.

param.name: start-index
param.doc: The start-index parameter specifies the index of the first matching result that should be included in the result set. This parameter uses a one-based index, meaning the first result is 1, the second result is 2 and so forth. This parameter works in conjunction with the max-results parameter to determine which results to return. For example, to request the second set of 10 results – i.e. results 11-20 – set the start-index parameter to 11 and the max-results parameter to 10.

param.name: strict
param.doc: The strict parameter can be used to instruct YouTube to reject an API request if the request contains invalid request parameters. The default API behavior is to ignore invalid request parameters. If you want YouTube to reject API requests that contain invalid parameters, set the strict parameter value to true. For example, YouTube would reject the following request because "foo" is not a valid request parameter.

param.name: v
param.doc: Specifies the version of the API that YouTube should use to handle the API request. Your request can specify the desired API version using either the v parameter or the GData-Version HTTP request header. If your request does not specify an API version, YouTube will handle your request using API version 1. The current API version is 2.

param.name: key
param.doc: The key parameter specifies your developer key, an alphanumeric string that uniquely identifies the application making an API request. You can also use the X-GData-Key request header to specify your developer key. Your application does not need to specify your developer key twice by using both the key parameter and the X-GData-Key request header, but it should provide your developer key using at least one of those two methods.

param.name: time
param.doc: Allows you to restrict the feed to only contain relevant results from the previous day, week or month. Note: The top_rated, top_favorites, most_viewed, most_discussed and most_responded standard feeds support the time parameter.

param.name: projection
param.doc: Projection name. All API requests must specify a projection. Most developers who are using this documentation will use the api projection. param.name: feedID
param.doc: Feed ID.

param.name: userType
param.doc: User type used to filter the standard channel feed. Valid user types that can be appended to the feed URL are Comedians, Directors, Gurus, Musicians, Non-profit, Partners, Politicians, Reporters, and Sponsors. See API docs for details. Note: If you request a standard channel feed for a specific user type, you can also specify a region but you cannot also specify a category name.

param.name: categoryName
param.doc: Category name for category-specific standard feeds. See API docs for a list of valid category values.

param.name: restriction
param.doc: Identifies the IP address that should be used to filter videos that can only be played in specific countries. To request videos playable from a specific computer, include the restriction parameter in your request and set the parameter value to the IP address of the computer where the videos will be played – e.g. restriction=255.255.255.255. To request videos that are playable in a specific country, include the restriction parameter in your request and set the parameter value to the ISO 3166 two-letter country code of the country where the videos will be played – e.g. restriction=DE.

The default value of this parameter is 25, and the maximum value is 50. However, for displaying lists of videos, we recommend that you set the max-results parameter to 10.

param.name: prettyprint
param.doc: The prettyprint parameter lets you request an XML response formatted with indentations and line breaks. Set the parameter's value to true to have the response formatted as such. The default parameter value is false.

param.name: start-index
param.doc: The start-index parameter specifies the index of the first matching result that should be included in the result set. This parameter uses a one-based index, meaning the first result is 1, the second result is 2 and so forth. This parameter works in conjunction with the max-results parameter to determine which results to return. For example, to request the second set of 10 results – i.e. results 11-20 – set the start-index parameter to 11 and the max-results parameter to 10.

param.name: strict
param.doc: The strict parameter can be used to instruct YouTube to reject an API request if the request contains invalid request parameters. The default API behavior is to ignore invalid request parameters. If you want YouTube to reject API requests that contain invalid parameters, set the strict parameter value to true. For example, YouTube would reject the following request because "foo" is not a valid request parameter.

param.name: v
param.doc: Specifies the version of the API that YouTube should use to handle the API request. Your request can specify the desired API version using either the v parameter or the GData-Version HTTP request header. If your request does not specify an API version, YouTube will handle your request using API version 1. The current API version is 2.

param.name: key
param.doc: The key parameter specifies your developer key, an alphanumeric string that uniquely identifies the application making an API request. You can also use the X-GData-Key request header to specify your developer key. Your application does not need to specify your developer key twice by using both the key parameter and the X-GData-Key request header, but it should provide your developer key using at least one of those two methods.

param.name: caption
param.doc: Enables you to restrict a search to videos that have or do not have caption tracks. To only request videos that have captions, set the caption parameter value to true. To only request videos that do not have captions, set the caption parameter value to false. Note: For backward-compatibility reasons, the API will also only return videos that have captions if you include the caption parameter but do not specify a parameter value.

param.name: category
param.doc: enables you to retrieve videos that are in a particular category or are tagged with a particular keyword or developer tag.

param.name: format
param.doc: Specifies that videos must be available in a particular video format. See API docs for a list of valid format values.

param.name: location
param.doc: Restricts the search to videos that have a geographical location specified in their metadata. See API docs for details.

param.name: location-radius
param.doc: In conjunction with the location parameter, defines a geographic area. If the geographic coordinates associated with a video fall within that area, then the video may be included in search results. The location-radius parameter value must be a floating point number followed by a measurement unit. Valid measurement units are m, km, ft and mi. For example, valid parameter values include "1500m", "5km", "10000ft" and "0.75mi". The API will return an error if the radius is greater than 1000 kilometers.

param.name: lr
param.doc: Restricts the search to videos that have a title, description or keywords in a specific language. Valid values for the lr parameter are ISO 639-1 two-letter language codes. You can also use the values zh-Hans for simplified Chinese and zh-Hant for traditional Chinese.

param.name: orderby
param.doc: Specifies the method that will be used to order entries in the API response. See API docs for valid values and more details.

param.name: q
param.doc: Specifies a search query term. See API docs for more details.

param.name: restriction
param.doc: Identifies the IP address that should be used to filter videos that can only be played in specific countries. To request videos playable from a specific computer, include the restriction parameter in your request and set the parameter value to the IP address of the computer where the videos will be played – e.g. restriction=255.255.255.255. To request videos that are playable in a specific country, include the restriction parameter in your request and set the parameter value to the ISO 3166 two-letter country code of the country where the videos will be played – e.g. restriction=DE.

param.name: safeSearch
param.doc: Indicates whether the search results should include restricted content as well as standard content. Accepted values: none, moderate, strict.

param.name: time
param.doc: Allows you to restrict the feed to only contain relevant results from the previous day, week or month. Note: The top_rated, top_favorites, most_viewed, most_discussed and most_responded standard feeds support the time parameter.

param.name: uploader
param.doc: Lets you restrict a query to YouTube partner videos. A YouTube partner is a person or organization that has been accepted into and participates in the YouTube Partner Program.

param.name: projection
param.doc: Projection name. All API requests must specify a projection. Most developers who are using this documentation will use the api projection. However, if you are developing applications for mobile devices, you can substitute mobile for api in any of the sample requests described in the API documentation. Similarly, if you prefer to use the base projection, which is well suited to feed readers, you can substitute base for api in any of the sample requests described in the API documentation.

param.name: category_or_tag
param.doc: Category or keyword parameter(s), specified in GData format. See API docs for more details. This parameter is optional -- you can use the category query parameter instead. However, either is required for this method.

method.name: GET
method.doc: Retrieves a feed of all of the videos that are in a particular category or that are associated with a particular keyword.

param.name: alt
param.doc: The alt parameter specifies the format of the feed to be returned. The default value is atom and this document only explains the format of Atom responses. If you set the parameter value to json-in-script, then you must also set the callback parameter value to identify the callback function to which the API response will be sent.

param.name: author
param.doc: The author parameter restricts the search to videos uploaded by a particular YouTube user. Requesting a standard feed, YouTube will retrieve the standard feed and then filter the response to only include videos uploaded by the specified author. For example, if you request the "Top Rated" feed for user GoogleDevelopers, the API will retrieve the top-rated feed and return a response containing videos in that feed uploaded by user GoogleDevelopers. The API will not return a list of that user's videos ordered by rating.

param.name: callback
param.doc: The callback parameter identifies the callback function to which the API response will be sent. If the value of the alt parameter is jsonc or json-in-script, and you specify a value for the callback parameter, then the API response will be wrapped in a call to the specified function. This parameter is required if the value of the alt parameter is json-in-script.

param.name: fields
param.doc: The fields parameter serves one or both of the following purposes: 1. It identifies the data fields that should be included in a partial API response. 2. It specifies conditions that should be used to filter the result set. See API docs for more details. Note: The fields parameter is currently used for experimental features only.

param.name: fields-language
param.doc: The fields-language parameter is being used temporarily to force the API server to apply new syntax rules affecting requests to retrieve partial API responses. To use the new syntax rules for partial API responses, or to filter results based on the presence of an element that does not contain text content, set the fields-language parameter value to r2. (This is the only valid value for this parameter.)

param.name: max-results

To use the new syntax rules for partial API responses, or to filter results based on the presence of an element that does not contain text content, set the fields-language parameter value to r2. (This is the only valid value for this parameter.)

param.name: prettyprint
param.doc: The prettyprint parameter lets you request an XML response formatted with indentations and line breaks. Set the parameter's value to true to have the response formatted as such. The default parameter value is false.

param.name: strict
param.doc: The strict parameter can be used to instruct YouTube to reject an API request if the request contains invalid request parameters. The default API behavior is to ignore invalid request parameters. If you want YouTube to reject API requests that contain invalid parameters, set the strict parameter value to true. For example, YouTube would reject the following request because "foo" is not a valid request parameter.

param.name: v
param.doc: Specifies the version of the API that YouTube should use to handle the API request. Your request can specify the desired API version using either the v parameter or the GData-Version HTTP request header. If your request does not specify an API version, YouTube will handle your request using API version 1. The current API version is 2.

param.name: key
param.doc: The key parameter specifies your developer key, an alphanumeric string that uniquely identifies the application making an API request. You can also use the X-GData-Key request header to specify your developer key. Your application does not need to specify your developer key twice by using both the key parameter and the X-GData-Key request header, but it should provide your developer key using at least one of those two methods.

param.name: projection
param.doc: Projection name. All API requests must specify a projection. Most developers who are using this documentation will use the api projection. However, if you are developing applications for mobile devices, you can substitute mobile for api in any of the sample requests described in the API documentation. Similarly, if you prefer to use the base projection, which is well suited to feed readers, you can substitute base for api in any of the sample requests described in the API documentation.

param.name: videoId
param.doc: The ID of the video to delete the video response from.

param.name: responseId
param.doc: The ID of the video response to delete.

method.name: DELETE
method.doc: Deletes a video response.

param.name: alt
param.doc: The alt parameter specifies the format of the feed to be returned. The default value is atom and this document only explains the format of Atom responses. If you set the parameter value to json-in-script, then you must also set the callback parameter value to identify the callback function to which the API response will be sent.

param.name: callback
param.doc: The callback parameter identifies the callback function to which the API response will be sent. If the value of the alt parameter is jsonc or json-in-script, and you specify a value for the callback parameter, then the API response will be wrapped in a call to the specified function. This parameter is required if the value of the alt parameter is json-in-script.

param.name: fields
param.doc: The fields parameter serves one or both of the following purposes: 1. It identifies the data fields that should be included in a partial API response. 2. It specifies conditions that should be used to filter the result set. See API docs for more details. Note: The fields parameter is currently used for experimental features only.

param.doc: The ID of the video to retrieve the related videos for.

method.name: GET
method.doc: Returns a list of related videos for a given video.

param.name: alt
param.doc: The alt parameter specifies the format of the feed to be returned. The default value is atom and this document only explains the format of Atom responses. If you set the parameter value to json-in-script, then you must also set the callback parameter value to identify the callback function to which the API response will be sent.

param.name: author
param.doc: The author parameter restricts the search to videos uploaded by a particular YouTube user. Requesting a standard feed, YouTube will retrieve the standard feed and then filter the response to only include videos uploaded by the specified author. For example, if you request the "Top Rated" feed for user GoogleDevelopers, the API will retrieve the top-rated feed and return a response containing videos in that feed uploaded by user GoogleDevelopers. The API will not return a list of that user's videos ordered by rating.

param.name: callback

(This is the only valid value for this parameter.)

param.name: max-results
param.doc: The max-results parameter specifies the maximum number of results that should be included in the result set. This parameter works in conjunction with the start-index parameter to determine which results to return. For example, to request the second set of 10 results – i.e. results 11-20 – set the max-results parameter to 10 and the start-index parameter to 11. The default value of this parameter is 25, and the maximum value is 50. However, for displaying lists of videos, we recommend that you set the max-results parameter to 10.

param.name: prettyprint
param.doc: The prettyprint parameter lets you request an XML response formatted with indentations and line breaks. Set the parameter's value to true to have the response formatted as such. The default parameter value is false.

param.name: start-index
param.doc: The start-index parameter specifies the index of the first matching result that should be included in the result set. This parameter uses a one-based index, meaning the first result is 1, the second result is 2 and so forth. This parameter works in conjunction with the max-results parameter to determine which results to return. For example, to request the second set of 10 results – i.e. results 11-20 – set the start-index parameter to 11 and the max-results parameter to 10.

However, if the identification fails, then your API request will also fail. If you do specify the caption track language, then you must also specify the character set used so that YouTube can decode the file. To specify the character set, add the charset parameter to the Content-Type header value.

If you do specify the caption track language, then you must also specify the character set used so that YouTube can decode the file. To specify the character set, add the charset parameter to the Content-Type header value.

param.name: Slug
param.doc: The title of the caption track.

param.name: projection
param.doc: Projection name. All API requests must specify a projection. Most developers who are using this documentation will use the api projection. However, if you are developing applications for mobile devices, you can substitute mobile for api in any of the sample requests described in the API documentation. Similarly, if you prefer to use the base projection, which is well suited to feed readers, you can substitute base for api in any of the sample requests described in the API documentation.

method.name: POST
method.doc: Submits a batch processing request to retrieve additional information about the videos identified in an activity feed.

param.name: alt
param.doc: The alt parameter specifies the format of the feed to be returned. The default value is atom and this document only explains the format of Atom responses. If you set the parameter value to json-in-script, then you must also set the callback parameter value to identify the callback function to which the API response will be sent.

param.name: author
param.doc: The author parameter restricts the search to videos uploaded by a particular YouTube user. Requesting a standard feed, YouTube will retrieve the standard feed and then filter the response to only include videos uploaded by the specified author. For example, if you request the "Top Rated" feed for user GoogleDevelopers, the API will retrieve the top-rated feed and return a response containing videos in that feed uploaded by user GoogleDevelopers. The API will not return a list of that user's videos ordered by rating.

param.name: callback
param.doc: The callback parameter identifies the callback function to which the API response will be sent. If the value of the alt parameter is jsonc or json-in-script, and you specify a value for the callback parameter, then the API response will be wrapped in a call to the specified function. This parameter is required if the value of the alt parameter is json-in-script.

param.name: fields
param.doc: The fields parameter serves one or both of the following purposes: 1. It identifies the data fields that should be included in a partial API response. 2. It specifies conditions that should be used to filter the result set. See API docs for more details. Note: The fields parameter is currently used for experimental features only.

param.name: fields-language
param.doc: The fields-language parameter is being used temporarily to force the API server to apply new syntax rules affecting requests to retrieve partial API responses. To use the new syntax rules for partial API responses, or to filter results based on the presence of an element that does not contain text content, set the fields-language parameter value to r2. (This is the only valid value for this parameter.)

param.name: max-results
param.doc: The max-results parameter specifies the maximum number of results that should be included in the result set. This parameter works in conjunction with the start-index parameter to determine which results to return. For example, to request the second set of 10 results – i.e. results 11-20 – set the max-results parameter to 10 and the start-index parameter to 11. The default value of this parameter is 25, and the maximum value is 50. However, for displaying lists of videos, we recommend that you set the max-results parameter to 10.

param.name: prettyprint
param.doc: The prettyprint parameter lets you request an XML response formatted with indentations and line breaks. Set the parameter's value to true to have the response formatted as such. The default parameter value is false.

param.name: start-index
param.doc: The start-index parameter specifies the index of the first matching result that should be included in the result set. This parameter uses a one-based index, meaning the first result is 1, the second result is 2 and so forth. This parameter works in conjunction with the max-results parameter to determine which results to return. For example, to request the second set of 10 results – i.e. results 11-20 – set the start-index parameter to 11 and the max-results parameter to 10.

param.name: strict
param.doc: The strict parameter can be used to instruct YouTube to reject an API request if the request contains invalid request parameters. The default API behavior is to ignore invalid request parameters. If you want YouTube to reject API requests that contain invalid parameters, set the strict parameter value to true. For example, YouTube would reject the following request because "foo" is not a valid request parameter.

param.name: v
param.doc: Specifies the version of the API that YouTube should use to handle the API request. Your request can specify the desired API version using either the v parameter or the GData-Version HTTP request header. If your request does not specify an API version, YouTube will handle your request using API version 1. The current API version is 2.

param.name: key
param.doc: The key parameter specifies your developer key, an alphanumeric string that uniquely identifies the application making an API request. You can also use the X-GData-Key request header to specify your developer key. Your application does not need to specify your developer key twice by using both the key parameter and the X-GData-Key request header, but it should provide your developer key using at least one of those two methods.

param.doc: Identifies the IP address that should be used to filter videos that can only be played in specific countries. To request videos playable from a specific computer, include the restriction parameter in your request and set the parameter value to the IP address of the computer where the videos will be played – e.g. restriction=255.255.255.255. To request videos that are playable in a specific country, include the restriction parameter in your request and set the parameter value to the ISO 3166 two-letter country code of the country where the videos will be played – e.g. restriction=DE.

However, if you are developing applications for mobile devices, you can substitute mobile for api in any of the sample requests described in the API documentation. Similarly, if you prefer to use the base projection, which is well suited to feed readers, you can substitute base for api in any of the sample requests described in the API documentation.

param.name: username
param.doc: The user whose playlist to update. Set this parameter to "default" to reference the currently logged-in user's playlists. Note: For this request, you must provide an authentication token in the Authorization HTTP request header. The authentication token enables YouTube to identify the user.

param.name: playlistId
param.doc: The ID of the playlist to update or delete.

method.name: PUT
method.doc: Updates playlist information, such as the title, description and public/private status of the playlist.

param.name: alt
param.doc: The alt parameter specifies the format of the feed to be returned. The default value is atom and this document only explains the format of Atom responses. If you set the parameter value to json-in-script, then you must also set the callback parameter value to identify the callback function to which the API response will be sent.

param.name: author
param.doc: The author parameter restricts the search to videos uploaded by a particular YouTube user. Requesting a standard feed, YouTube will retrieve the standard feed and then filter the response to only include videos uploaded by the specified author. For example, if you request the "Top Rated" feed for user GoogleDevelopers, the API will retrieve the top-rated feed and return a response containing videos in that feed uploaded by user GoogleDevelopers. The API will not return a list of that user's videos ordered by rating.

param.name: callback
param.doc: The callback parameter identifies the callback function to which the API response will be sent. If the value of the alt parameter is jsonc or json-in-script, and you specify a value for the callback parameter, then the API response will be wrapped in a call to the specified function. This parameter is required if the value of the alt parameter is json-in-script.

param.name: fields
param.doc: The fields parameter serves one or both of the following purposes: 1. It identifies the data fields that should be included in a partial API response. 2. It specifies conditions that should be used to filter the result set. See API docs for more details. Note: The fields parameter is currently used for experimental features only.

param.name: fields-language
param.doc: The fields-language parameter is being used temporarily to force the API server to apply new syntax rules affecting requests to retrieve partial API responses. To use the new syntax rules for partial API responses, or to filter results based on the presence of an element that does not contain text content, set the fields-language parameter value to r2. (This is the only valid value for this parameter.)

param.name: max-results
param.doc: The max-results parameter specifies the maximum number of results that should be included in the result set. This parameter works in conjunction with the start-index parameter to determine which results to return. For example, to request the second set of 10 results – i.e. results 11-20 – set the max-results parameter to 10 and the start-index parameter to 11. The default value of this parameter is 25, and the maximum value is 50. However, for displaying lists of videos, we recommend that you set the max-results parameter to 10.

param.name: prettyprint
param.doc: The prettyprint parameter lets you request an XML response formatted with indentations and line breaks. Set the parameter's value to true to have the response formatted as such. The default parameter value is false.

param.name: start-index
param.doc: The start-index parameter specifies the index of the first matching result that should be included in the result set. This parameter uses a one-based index, meaning the first result is 1, the second result is 2 and so forth. This parameter works in conjunction with the max-results parameter to determine which results to return. For example, to request the second set of 10 results – i.e. results 11-20 – set the start-index parameter to 11 and the max-results parameter to 10.

param.name: strict
param.doc: The strict parameter can be used to instruct YouTube to reject an API request if the request contains invalid request parameters. The default API behavior is to ignore invalid request parameters. If you want YouTube to reject API requests that contain invalid parameters, set the strict parameter value to true. For example, YouTube would reject the following request because "foo" is not a valid request parameter.

param.name: v
param.doc: Specifies the version of the API that YouTube should use to handle the API request. Your request can specify the desired API version using either the v parameter or the GData-Version HTTP request header. If your request does not specify an API version, YouTube will handle your request using API version 1. The current API version is 2.

param.name: key
param.doc: The key parameter specifies your developer key, an alphanumeric string that uniquely identifies the application making an API request. You can also use the X-GData-Key request header to specify your developer key. Your application does not need to specify your developer key twice by using both the key parameter and the X-GData-Key request header, but it should provide your developer key using at least one of those two methods.

param.name: restriction
param.doc: Identifies the IP address that should be used to filter videos that can only be played in specific countries. To request videos playable from a specific computer, include the restriction parameter in your request and set the parameter value to the IP address of the computer where the videos will be played – e.g. restriction=255.255.255.255. To request videos that are playable in a specific country, include the restriction parameter in your request and set the parameter value to the ISO 3166 two-letter country code of the country where the videos will be played – e.g. restriction=DE.

method.name: DELETE
method.doc: Deletes a playlist.

(This is the only valid value for this parameter.)

param.name: max-results
param.doc: The max-results parameter specifies the maximum number of results that should be included in the result set. This parameter works in conjunction with the start-index parameter to determine which results to return. For example, to request the second set of 10 results – i.e. results 11-20 – set the max-results parameter to 10 and the start-index parameter to 11. The default value of this parameter is 25, and the maximum value is 50. However, for displaying lists of videos, we recommend that you set the max-results parameter to 10.

param.name: prettyprint
param.doc: The prettyprint parameter lets you request an XML response formatted with indentations and line breaks. Set the parameter's value to true to have the response formatted as such. The default parameter value is false.

param.name: start-index
param.doc: The start-index parameter specifies the index of the first matching result that should be included in the result set. This parameter uses a one-based index, meaning the first result is 1, the second result is 2 and so forth. This parameter works in conjunction with the max-results parameter to determine which results to return. For example, to request the second set of 10 results – i.e. results 11-20 – set the start-index parameter to 11 and the max-results parameter to 10.

param.name: strict
param.doc: The strict parameter can be used to instruct YouTube to reject an API request if the request contains invalid request parameters. The default API behavior is to ignore invalid request parameters. If you want YouTube to reject API requests that contain invalid parameters, set the strict parameter value to true. For example, YouTube would reject the following request because "foo" is not a valid request parameter.

param.name: alt
param.doc: The alt parameter specifies the format of the feed to be returned. The default value is atom and this document only explains the format of Atom responses. param.name: author
param.doc: The author parameter restricts the search to videos uploaded by a particular YouTube user. Requesting a standard feed, YouTube will retrieve the standard feed and then filter the response to only include videos uploaded by the specified author. For example, if you request the "Top Rated" feed for user GoogleDevelopers, the API will retrieve the top-rated feed and return a response containing videos in that feed uploaded by user GoogleDevelopers. The API will not return a list of that user's videos ordered by rating.

Your request can specify the desired API version using either the v parameter or the GData-Version HTTP request header. If your request does not specify an API version, YouTube will handle your request using API version 1. The current API version is 2.

param.name: key
param.doc: The key parameter specifies your developer key, an alphanumeric string that uniquely identifies the application making an API request. You can also use the X-GData-Key request header to specify your developer key. Your application does not need to specify your developer key twice by using both the key parameter and the X-GData-Key request header, but it should provide your developer key using at least one of those two methods.

method.name: PUT
method.doc: Updates video information. The body of the PUT request is an Atom XML entry that contains information about the video. See API docs for more details.

param.name: key
param.doc: The key parameter specifies your developer key, an alphanumeric string that uniquely identifies the application making an API request. You can also use the X-GData-Key request header to specify your developer key. Your application does not need to specify your developer key twice by using both the key parameter and the X-GData-Key request header, but it should provide your developer key using at least one of those two methods.

method.name: DELETE
method.doc: Deletes a video.

param.name: key
param.doc: The key parameter specifies your developer key, an alphanumeric string that uniquely identifies the application making an API request. You can also use the X-GData-Key request header to specify your developer key. Your application does not need to specify your developer key twice by using both the key parameter and the X-GData-Key request header, but it should provide your developer key using at least one of those two methods.

param.name: projection
param.doc: Projection name. All API requests must specify a projection. Most developers who are using this documentation will use the api projection. However, if you are developing applications for mobile devices, you can substitute mobile for api in any of the sample requests described in the API documentation. Similarly, if you prefer to use the base projection, which is well suited to feed readers, you can substitute base for api in any of the sample requests described in the API documentation.

param.name: username
param.doc: The user whose live events to retrieve. Set this parameter to "default" to request a feed of the currently logged-in user's live events. Note: For this request, you must provide an authentication token in the Authorization HTTP request header. The authentication token enables YouTube to identify the user.

method.name: GET
method.doc: Retrieves a feed listing a specific user's live-streaming events.

param.name: alt
param.doc: The alt parameter specifies the format of the feed to be returned. The default value is atom and this document only explains the format of Atom responses. If you set the parameter value to json-in-script, then you must also set the callback parameter value to identify the callback function to which the API response will be sent.

param.name: author
param.doc: The author parameter restricts the search to videos uploaded by a particular YouTube user. Requesting a standard feed, YouTube will retrieve the standard feed and then filter the response to only include videos uploaded by the specified author. For example, if you request the "Top Rated" feed for user GoogleDevelopers, the API will retrieve the top-rated feed and return a response containing videos in that feed uploaded by user GoogleDevelopers. The API will not return a list of that user's videos ordered by rating.

param.name: callback
param.doc: The callback parameter identifies the callback function to which the API response will be sent. If the value of the alt parameter is jsonc or json-in-script, and you specify a value for the callback parameter, then the API response will be wrapped in a call to the specified function. This parameter is required if the value of the alt parameter is json-in-script.

param.name: fields
param.doc: The fields parameter serves one or both of the following purposes: 1. It identifies the data fields that should be included in a partial API response. 2. It specifies conditions that should be used to filter the result set. See API docs for more details. Note: The fields parameter is currently used for experimental features only.

param.name: fields-language
param.doc: The fields-language parameter is being used temporarily to force the API server to apply new syntax rules affecting requests to retrieve partial API responses. To use the new syntax rules for partial API responses, or to filter results based on the presence of an element that does not contain text content, set the fields-language parameter value to r2. (This is the only valid value for this parameter.)

param.name: max-results
param.doc: The max-results parameter specifies the maximum number of results that should be included in the result set. This parameter works in conjunction with the start-index parameter to determine which results to return. For example, to request the second set of 10 results – i.e. results 11-20 – set the max-results parameter to 10 and the start-index parameter to 11. The default value of this parameter is 25, and the maximum value is 50. However, for displaying lists of videos, we recommend that you set the max-results parameter to 10.

param.name: prettyprint
param.doc: The prettyprint parameter lets you request an XML response formatted with indentations and line breaks. Set the parameter's value to true to have the response formatted as such. The default parameter value is false.

param.name: start-index
param.doc: The start-index parameter specifies the index of the first matching result that should be included in the result set. This parameter uses a one-based index, meaning the first result is 1, the second result is 2 and so forth. This parameter works in conjunction with the max-results parameter to determine which results to return. For example, to request the second set of 10 results – i.e. results 11-20 – set the start-index parameter to 11 and the max-results parameter to 10.

param.name: strict
param.doc: The strict parameter can be used to instruct YouTube to reject an API request if the request contains invalid request parameters. The default API behavior is to ignore invalid request parameters. If you want YouTube to reject API requests that contain invalid parameters, set the strict parameter value to true. For example, YouTube would reject the following request because "foo" is not a valid request parameter.

param.name: v
param.doc: Specifies the version of the API that YouTube should use to handle the API request. Your request can specify the desired API version using either the v parameter or the GData-Version HTTP request header. If your request does not specify an API version, YouTube will handle your request using API version 1. The current API version is 2.

param.name: key
param.doc: The key parameter specifies your developer key, an alphanumeric string that uniquely identifies the application making an API request. You can also use the X-GData-Key request header to specify your developer key. Your application does not need to specify your developer key twice by using both the key parameter and the X-GData-Key request header, but it should provide your developer key using at least one of those two methods.

param.name: status
param.doc: Restricts a live event feed to only list events with the specified status.

param.name: starts-before
param.doc: Restricts the feed to only include events that began or are scheduled to begin at or before the specified date and time. The parameter value must be a date or a date and time in ISO 8601 format.

param.name: starts-after
param.doc: Restricts the feed to only include events that began or are scheduled to begin at or after the specified date and time. The parameter value must be a date or a date and time in ISO 8601 format.

param.name: ends-before
param.doc: Restricts the feed to only include events that ended or are scheduled to end at or after the specified date and time. The parameter value must be a date or a date and time in ISO 8601 format.

param.name: ends-after
param.doc: Restricts a feed to only include events that ended or are scheduled to end at or before the specified date and time. The parameter value must be a date or a date and time in ISO 8601 format.

param.name: inline
param.doc: Indicates whether events in the feed will include a live video entry or a playlist entry that contains information about the event's video stream or streams, respectively. If an entry is inlined, it will be encapsulated inside the event entry's <content> element. Set the parameter value to true to specify that video (or playlist) entries should be embedded in the event entries.

param.name: projection
param.doc: Projection name. All API requests must specify a projection. Most developers who are using this documentation will use the api projection. However, if you are developing applications for mobile devices, you can substitute mobile for api in any of the sample requests described in the API documentation. Similarly, if you prefer to use the base projection, which is well suited to feed readers, you can substitute base for api in any of the sample requests described in the API documentation.

param.doc: Filters a chart to only include movies that are in a particular genre.

param.name: paid-content
param.doc: Filters a chart to only include either paid content or free content. If the parameter is not set, a chart can include both paid and free content.

param.name: region
param.doc: Filters a chart to only include movies that are viewable in a particular territory. The parameter value is an ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 code that identifies the country where videos must be viewable to be included in search results.

param.name: projection
param.doc: Projection name. All API requests must specify a projection. Most developers who are using this documentation will use the api projection. However, if you are developing applications for mobile devices, you can substitute mobile for api in any of the sample requests described in the API documentation. Similarly, if you prefer to use the base projection, which is well suited to feed readers, you can substitute base for api in any of the sample requests described in the API documentation.

param.name: feedId
param.doc: Feed ID.

method.name: GET
method.doc: Returns one of several different standard feeds, or charts, listing live events on YouTube.

param.name: alt
param.doc: The alt parameter specifies the format of the feed to be returned. The default value is atom and this document only explains the format of Atom responses. If you set the parameter value to json-in-script, then you must also set the callback parameter value to identify the callback function to which the API response will be sent.

param.name: author
param.doc: The author parameter restricts the search to videos uploaded by a particular YouTube user. Requesting a standard feed, YouTube will retrieve the standard feed and then filter the response to only include videos uploaded by the specified author. For example, if you request the "Top Rated" feed for user GoogleDevelopers, the API will retrieve the top-rated feed and return a response containing videos in that feed uploaded by user GoogleDevelopers. The API will not return a list of that user's videos ordered by rating.

param.name: callback
param.doc: The callback parameter identifies the callback function to which the API response will be sent. If the value of the alt parameter is jsonc or json-in-script, and you specify a value for the callback parameter, then the API response will be wrapped in a call to the specified function. This parameter is required if the value of the alt parameter is json-in-script.

param.name: fields
param.doc: The fields parameter serves one or both of the following purposes: 1. It identifies the data fields that should be included in a partial API response. 2. It specifies conditions that should be used to filter the result set. See API docs for more details. Note: The fields parameter is currently used for experimental features only.

param.name: fields-language
param.doc: The fields-language parameter is being used temporarily to force the API server to apply new syntax rules affecting requests to retrieve partial API responses. To use the new syntax rules for partial API responses, or to filter results based on the presence of an element that does not contain text content, set the fields-language parameter value to r2. (This is the only valid value for this parameter.)

param.name: max-results
param.doc: The max-results parameter specifies the maximum number of results that should be included in the result set. This parameter works in conjunction with the start-index parameter to determine which results to return. For example, to request the second set of 10 results – i.e. results 11-20 – set the max-results parameter to 10 and the start-index parameter to 11. The default value of this parameter is 25, and the maximum value is 50. However, for displaying lists of videos, we recommend that you set the max-results parameter to 10.

param.name: prettyprint
param.doc: The prettyprint parameter lets you request an XML response formatted with indentations and line breaks. Set the parameter's value to true to have the response formatted as such. The default parameter value is false.

param.name: start-index
param.doc: The start-index parameter specifies the index of the first matching result that should be included in the result set. This parameter uses a one-based index, meaning the first result is 1, the second result is 2 and so forth. This parameter works in conjunction with the max-results parameter to determine which results to return. For example, to request the second set of 10 results – i.e. results 11-20 – set the start-index parameter to 11 and the max-results parameter to 10.

param.name: strict
param.doc: The strict parameter can be used to instruct YouTube to reject an API request if the request contains invalid request parameters. The default API behavior is to ignore invalid request parameters. If you want YouTube to reject API requests that contain invalid parameters, set the strict parameter value to true. For example, YouTube would reject the following request because "foo" is not a valid request parameter.

param.name: v
param.doc: Specifies the version of the API that YouTube should use to handle the API request. Your request can specify the desired API version using either the v parameter or the GData-Version HTTP request header. If your request does not specify an API version, YouTube will handle your request using API version 1. The current API version is 2.

param.name: key
param.doc: The key parameter specifies your developer key, an alphanumeric string that uniquely identifies the application making an API request. You can also use the X-GData-Key request header to specify your developer key. Your application does not need to specify your developer key twice by using both the key parameter and the X-GData-Key request header, but it should provide your developer key using at least one of those two methods.

param.name: status
param.doc: Restricts a live event feed to only list events with the specified status.

param.name: starts-before
param.doc: Restricts the feed to only include events that began or are scheduled to begin at or before the specified date and time. The parameter value must be a date or a date and time in ISO 8601 format.

param.name: starts-after
param.doc: Restricts the feed to only include events that began or are scheduled to begin at or after the specified date and time. The parameter value must be a date or a date and time in ISO 8601 format.

param.name: ends-before
param.doc: Restricts the feed to only include events that ended or are scheduled to end at or after the specified date and time. The parameter value must be a date or a date and time in ISO 8601 format.

param.name: ends-after
param.doc: Restricts a feed to only include events that ended or are scheduled to end at or before the specified date and time. The parameter value must be a date or a date and time in ISO 8601 format.

param.name: region
param.doc: Filters a chart to only include movies that are viewable in a particular territory. The parameter value is an ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 code that identifies the country where videos must be viewable to be included in search results.

param.name: projection
param.doc: Projection name. All API requests must specify a projection. Most developers who are using this documentation will use the api projection. However, if you are developing applications for mobile devices, you can substitute mobile for api in any of the sample requests described in the API documentation. Similarly, if you prefer to use the base projection, which is well suited to feed readers, you can substitute base for api in any of the sample requests described in the API documentation.

param.name: q
param.doc: Specifies a search query term. See API docs for more details.

method.name: GET
method.doc: Retrieves YouTube's Simple Update Protocol (SUP) feed.

param.name: callback
param.doc: The callback parameter identifies the callback function to which the API response will be sent. If the value of the alt parameter is jsonc or json-in-script, and you specify a value for the callback parameter, then the API response will be wrapped in a call to the specified function. param.name: seconds
param.doc: Specifies a time interval, in seconds, during which the activity feeds to be returned have been changed.

param.name: projection
param.doc: Projection name. All API requests must specify a projection. Most developers who are using this documentation will use the api projection. However, if you are developing applications for mobile devices, you can substitute mobile for api in any of the sample requests described in the API documentation. Similarly, if you prefer to use the base projection, which is well suited to feed readers, you can substitute base for api in any of the sample requests described in the API documentation.

param.name: username
param.doc: The user associated with the uploads. Set this parameter to "default" to reference the currently logged-in user. Note: For this request, you must provide an authentication token in the Authorization HTTP request header. The authentication token enables YouTube to identify the user.

method.name: POST
method.doc: Uploads a video (direct upload). See API docs for request format.

param.name: Slug
param.doc: The filename of the video being uploaded.

param.name: projection
param.doc: Projection name. All API requests must specify a projection. Most developers who are using this documentation will use the api projection. param.name: Slug

param.name: id
param.doc: The ID of the resumable upload, as returned by a POST request to /resumable/feeds/api/users/{user}/uploads

method.name: PUT
method.doc: Uploads video content as part of a resumable upload.

method.doc: Returns viewing statistics, popularity metrics and demographic information for videos and channels via YouTube Insight.
